g.text: In fact, future change in the circulation over the Mediterranean exhibits a rather inhomogeneous spatial pat-
tern. Previous study has proposed that the descending motion over the Western Mediterranean (WM, 0–20° E,
25°–45° N) is expected to strengthen, whereas that over the Eastern Mediterranean (EM) is anticipated to weaken
. The descending motion changes over the Mediterranean has been attributed to the local circu-
lation change as well as monsoon induced heating
. The latter is the main source according to the monsoon–
. However, except for the SASM-related forcing, there exist various forcing mechanisms such as
the EASM, West African monsoon, and Atlantic Intertropical Convergence Zone. Therefore, the whole picture of
physical processes causing the circulation changes over the Mediterranean needs to be investigated.
future changes in the Mediterranean atmospheric circulation.
wind (omega) and precipitation minus evaporation (P–E) during June–July–August (JJA) between the present
climate (20 C) and future climate (21 C) are shown in Fig.
to positive omega, black contour in Fig.
) is grossly located over 25°–45° N in the boreal summer. In particular,
the descending motion over the EM (20°–40° E) is much stronger than that over other regions along 35° N. The
climatological P–E value is negative across this subsidence region, implying a dry and warm climate, except in the
). On the other hand, future changes (shaded in Fig.
over the WM (5°–20° E) but the negative omega anomalies over the EM. The result reveals that the descending
motion would become stronger in the WM but with weaker descending motion in the EM in the future (Fig.
which is in agreement with a previous study
. The circulation change tends to drive the gross feature of the P–E
change; the drier atmosphere over the WM and the wetter one over the EM, although the latter P–E signal is
. Furthermore, widespread downward motion anomalies are seen along 40°–50° N (Fig.
the poleward shift in the subtropical dry zone under warmer climate conditions
Remote heat sources inducing the atmospheric circulation change.
ered a major remote forcing component inducing changes in the Mediterranean climate. However, this is not
the only forcing source. To identify what additional heat sources are responsible for the atmospheric circulation
change over the Mediterranean, the numerical experiments using Linear Balance Model (LBM) are performed.
The input diabatic heating or cooling profiles are taken from the simulation outputs for the regions denoting the
SASM, EASM, Atlantic, and Africa (indicated by the boxes in Supplementary Fig. S1b). The omega anomalies in
0.550) for the near steady state (which is achieved by the average over 25–29 day
integration outputs) are shown in Fig.
for different heat sources. The results are not sensitive to the addition or
exclusion of a few days after the 15-day integrations. The omega anomalies over 30°–40° N for the SASM forcing
) show the generally similar zonal pattern to that of the 21 C CMIP5 omega changes (Fig.
anomaly over the WM and negative one over the nearby EM, although these two anomalies are shifted by 5° to the

). The contour intervals are 0.02 Pa s
points where more than 85% of the models agree on the sign of the mean for future change. In (
